name: Dashboard Layout with Collapsible Sidebar
description: A responsive admin dashboard layout with collapsible sidebar navigation, fixed header, and fixed footer. Perfect for admin panels, SaaS applications, and data-driven interfaces.

invariants: Header and footer are always visible on desktop
Content scrolls independently (not the page body) when possible
Content area accounts for fixed header and footer heights
No horizontal page scroll is introduced by sidebar transitions

aiAgentInstructions.summary: Implement a four-section dashboard layout (sidebar, header, content, footer) with collapsible sidebar functionality. The layout is framework-agnostic and should adapt to the user's chosen stack (React, Vue, Angular, Svelte, etc.) and styling approach (Tailwind, CSS Modules, Chakra UI, Material-UI, etc.).
keyFeatures: Fixed collapsible sidebar (280px expanded, 80px collapsed by default)
Fixed header that adjusts to sidebar state (64px height)
Fixed footer that adjusts to sidebar state (60px height)
Scrollable main content area with smooth transitions
Content area accounts for header and footer spacing
Full keyboard accessibility with ARIA labels
CRITICAL: Styling MUST match the project's existing conventions. Detect framework and styling system first, then use ONLY that system. Do NOT introduce new styling systems.

CRITICAL: When detecting vanilla CSS, ALWAYS create CSS classes in a stylesheet. NEVER use inline style attributes on HTML elements. Define classes like .sidebar, .sidebar--collapsed, .header, etc. and apply them via className/class attributes.

CRITICAL: When detecting React, extract logic from useEffect hooks into separate custom hooks that do ONE thing each. For example: useSidebarState(), useLocalStorage(), useBodyScrollLock(), useFocusTrap(). This improves code organization, testability, and reusability.
implementationSteps: 0. CRITICAL: Detect the project's framework and styling system BEFORE writing any code. Examine: (a) package.json for framework (React, Vue, Angular, Svelte) and styling dependencies (tailwindcss, styled-components, emotion, sass, etc.), (b) existing component files to see how they import styles (CSS Modules, Tailwind classes, styled-components, etc.), (c) config files (tailwind.config.js, vite.config.js, webpack.config.js, etc.), (d) existing style files and their structure. If the project uses Tailwind, use Tailwind. If SCSS/CSS, use SCSS/CSS. If styled-components, use styled-components. If nothing is configured, use the most suitable CSS approach (vanilla CSS or CSS Modules).
0a. Detect framework patterns: Check how existing components are structured (hooks in React, composition API in Vue, etc.), how state is managed, and what patterns are used.

0b. Detect styling conventions: Identify class naming (BEM, camelCase, kebab-case), how styles are imported, whether there's a design system or token system, and what utility functions exist (cn, clsx, classnames, etc.).
0c. If detection is uncertain, ask the user about their styling approach and framework before proceeding.
1. Create four main layout components: Sidebar, Header, Footer, and ContentArea
2. Implement state management for sidebar collapsed (desktop) and sidebar open (mobile overlay)
3. Add localStorage persistence for sidebar collapsed state (desktop)
4. Implement mobile-responsive overlay behavior with backdrop and body scroll lock
5. Position header and footer as fixed elements (top and bottom)
6. Adjust header and footer start offset based on sidebar state on desktop
7. Add padding-top and padding-bottom (or margins) to content area for header/footer spacing
8. Add smooth transitions (default 300ms) for all state changes
9. Implement keyboard navigation and ARIA attributes
10. Use ONLY the detected styling system. Do NOT add <style> blocks, inline styles, or new CSS files unless that's the project's convention. Match existing component styling patterns exactly.
11. Style according to the detected framework and styling system, using only existing project conventions

react.stateManagement: useState for component state, custom hooks for localStorage (SSR-safe), Context API or props for sharing state
react.example: const [collapsed, setCollapsed] = useState(false); const { value: persistedCollapsed, setValue: setPersistedCollapsed } = useLocalStorage('uipotion.dashboard.sidebarCollapsed.v1', false); useEffect(() => { setCollapsed(persistedCollapsed); }, [persistedCollapsed]);
react.customHooks: Extract logic into separate hooks: useLocalStorage(key, defaultValue), useBodyScrollLock(isLocked), useFocusTrap(containerRef, isActive), useSidebarState(). Each hook should handle ONE concern only.

vue.stateManagement: ref() or reactive() for state, watch() for localStorage, provide/inject for sharing

angular.stateManagement: Component properties, RxJS BehaviorSubject for shared state, Angular services for persistence
angular.example: private sidebarCollapsed$ = new BehaviorSubject<boolean>(false); ngAfterViewInit(){ const v = localStorage.getItem('uipotion.dashboard.sidebarCollapsed.v1'); this.sidebarCollapsed$.next(v === 'true'); }

svelte.stateManagement: writable stores for state, onMount for localStorage
svelte.example: import { writable } from 'svelte/store'; export const sidebarCollapsed = writable(false); onMount(() => { sidebarCollapsed.set(localStorage.getItem('uipotion.dashboard.sidebarCollapsed.v1') === 'true'); });

stylingApproaches.note: These are implementation examples showing how to apply the designSystem specifications using different styling tools. The designSystem section contains the authoritative design values that should be implemented regardless of styling approach.

tailwindCSS.description: Use utility classes with dynamic classes based on state. Use arbitrary values for exact pixel values matching tokens.
tailwindCSS.sidebarExample: class='fixed inset-y-0 start-0 h-full w-[280px] transition-all duration-300' :class="{'w-20': collapsed}"
tailwindCSS.headerExample: class='fixed top-0 h-16 transition-all duration-300' :class="{'start-[280px]': !collapsed, 'start-20': collapsed}"
tailwindCSS.footerExample: class='fixed bottom-0 h-[60px] transition-all duration-300' :class="{'start-[280px]': !collapsed, 'start-20': collapsed}"
tailwindCSS.key: Prefer logical properties (start/ms) where available for RTL friendliness. Use arbitrary values for pixel-perfect sizes.
tailwindCSS.note: Map token values (280/80/64/60) directly. If your Tailwind setup lacks logical property utilities, use left/ml and add RTL handling separately.

cssModules.description: Scoped CSS classes with conditional class names. Apply token values directly in CSS.
cssModules.approach: Define .sidebar and .sidebarCollapsed, .headerShifted, .footerShifted using token values. Toggle via className logic.
cssModules.note: Prefer logical properties where possible (margin-inline-start) to support RTL.

styledComponents.description: CSS-in-JS with props. Map token values to component props.
styledComponents.approach: Pass collapsed prop and adjust styles dynamically using token values
styledComponents.note: Extract tokens into a shared constants module or theme.

chakraUI.components: Use Drawer (permanent variant on desktop, temporary on mobile), Box for content
chakraUI.approach: Use Chakra Drawer with responsive variants; override widths/heights using token values.
chakraUI.theme: Extend Chakra theme with designSystem + tokens
chakraUI.transitions: Respect prefers-reduced-motion and use Chakra transition helpers

materialUI.components: Use MUI Drawer (permanent variant on desktop, temporary on mobile), AppBar for header
materialUI.approach: Drawer variant='permanent' desktop, 'temporary' mobile; customize widths with token values.
materialUI.theme: Override MUI theme to match designSystem + tokens
materialUI.transitions: Use theme transitions; ensure z-index aligns with tokens.layout.zIndex

vanillaCSS.description: Standard CSS with class toggles. Apply token values directly.
vanillaCSS.approach: Define classes with transitions using token values; toggle via JS. CRITICAL: ALWAYS create CSS classes in a stylesheet. NEVER use inline style attributes on HTML elements.
vanillaCSS.note: Prefer logical inset/margin properties for RTL. Apply classes via className/class attribute: <aside class='sidebar sidebar--collapsed'> NOT <aside style='width: 80px'>

sass.description: SCSS with variables and mixins. Define token values as SCSS variables.
sass.approach: Create SCSS variables for token values; use mixins for transitions and offsets.
sass.note: Map tokens + designSystem specifications to variables for maintainability.

framework.description: Detect the project's framework by examining package.json, existing component files, and project structure. Common frameworks: React, Vue, Angular, Svelte.
detectionSteps: Check package.json for framework dependencies (react, vue, @angular/core, svelte)
Examine existing component files for framework-specific patterns (JSX for React, .vue files for Vue, etc.)
Check build configuration (vite.config.js, webpack.config.js, angular.json, etc.)
Look for framework-specific directories (src/components, src/app, etc.)

stylingSystem.description: Detect the project's styling approach by examining dependencies, config files, and existing component styles. Use the detected system exclusively.
detectionSteps: Check package.json for styling dependencies: tailwindcss, styled-components, emotion, sass, less, css-modules, etc.
Look for config files: tailwind.config.js, postcss.config.js, sass config, etc.
Examine existing component files to see how styles are imported and used
Check for style files: .css, .scss, .module.css, styled-components patterns, etc.
Identify class naming conventions and utility functions (cn, clsx, classnames, etc.)
If no styling system is detected, use vanilla CSS or CSS Modules as the most suitable approach
adaptationRules: If Tailwind is detected: Use Tailwind utility classes, respect existing config, use existing design tokens, follow project's class composition patterns
If SCSS/CSS is detected: Use SCSS/CSS files matching project structure, follow existing naming conventions (BEM, camelCase, etc.), import styles as the project does
If styled-components is detected: Use styled-components syntax matching project patterns, follow existing component structure
If CSS Modules is detected: Use .module.css files, follow existing module naming patterns
If no styling system: Use vanilla CSS with semantic class names, or CSS Modules if it seems appropriate for the project size

detectionSteps: Check for design token files (tokens.json, theme.js, design-tokens.css, etc.)
Examine Tailwind config for theme values if using Tailwind
Look at existing components for color, spacing, and typography patterns
Check CSS variables (--color-*, --spacing-*, etc.) in global styles
If tokens exist, use them. If not, use values that match existing component styles

mustNot: Do NOT introduce new styling systems (if project uses Tailwind, don't add SCSS; if SCSS, don't add Tailwind)

CRITICAL: When vanilla CSS is detected, NEVER use inline style attributes on HTML elements. ALWAYS create CSS classes in a stylesheet and apply them via className/class. Example: Create .sidebar { width: 280px; } in CSS, then use <aside class='sidebar'> not <aside style='width: 280px'>

CRITICAL: When React is detected, NEVER put multiple concerns in a single useEffect. ALWAYS extract logic into separate custom hooks. Example: Instead of useEffect(() => { /* localStorage + scroll lock + focus trap */ }), create useLocalStorage(), useBodyScrollLock(), useFocusTrap() hooks and use them separately

aiImplementationPrompt: Create a responsive dashboard layout with a collapsible sidebar (default 280px expanded, 80px collapsed), fixed header (64px height), fixed footer (60px height), and scrollable content area. The sidebar should overlay on mobile (<768px) and persist its collapsed state (desktop) in localStorage using key 'uipotion.dashboard.sidebarCollapsed.v1'. Both header and footer should adjust their start offset based on sidebar state (280px when expanded, 80px when collapsed on desktop). Content area should account for fixed header/footer offsets (top 64px, bottom 60px) and avoid horizontal page scrolling. Include smooth 300ms transitions, keyboard accessibility with ARIA labels, and active state highlighting for current page. Ensure overlay behavior includes backdrop dismissal, focus trap, focus restoration, body scroll lock, and inert background content. Respect prefers-reduced-motion and apply mobile safe-area insets. Adapt the implementation to use {{USER_FRAMEWORK}} with {{USER_STYLING_LIBRARY}}. Include mobile menu toggle, user dropdown, and notifications button in the header. Footer should contain copyright and navigation links. CRITICAL: If vanilla CSS is detected, create CSS classes in a stylesheet, never use inline styles. If React is detected, extract useEffect logic into separate custom hooks (one concern per hook).
